Task.TaskDescription: Problem: Today, approximately 500,000 trees stand tall in Hardwood Forest. Due to careful forestry management, 99% of the trees are hardwood trees. The rest are softwood trees. Thus, Hardwood Forest is very valuable, because the market price of a softwood tree is only 33% of the market price of a hardwood tree. Hardwood is currently sold at $9.00 per square foot. With this price of hardwood, softwood would be $3.0 per square foot. Lumber companies are strongly constrained by government regulations. The number of trees they can harvest each year is only 5% of the total number of trees in the forest that year. An environmental group is worried that the forest will be entirely destroyed, so they plant 10,000 new trees each year. Goal: Graph the total number of trees in the forest over a 30-year period.
Task.ShortDescription:
the number of trees in the hardwood forest at the end of this year = 
 the number of trees in the forest at the end of the previous year 
 - the number of trees harvested this year 
 + the number of trees planted this year. 
 The initial number of trees in the forest is 500,000. 
the number of trees harvested each year = 
 the number of trees in the forest at the beginning of the year 
 * the proportion of trees harvested this year. 
The proportion of trees harvested each year is given as 0.05. 
the number of trees planted each year is given as 10,000. 
 The proportion of the forest that is hardwood trees is given as 0.99. 
 The market price of a softwood tree = 
 the ratio of the price of a softwood tree to a hardwood tree 
 * the market price of a hardwood tree. 
 The ratio of the price of a softwood tree to a hardwood tree is given as 0.33. 
 The cost of hardwood lumber per square foot in the current market is given as 9
